history.content:
Background for the validation of my response: I am a Head TA and have reviewed a fair chunk of applications. I am also an Executive member for CSM, and coordinate and interview for CS61B. 

With CSM, you're teaching a small section and gaining teaching experience. CS70 and 61B have interviews where teaching effectivenss is an important aspect. CSM will (probably) give you more hands on teaching experience. Being a reader typically means that you do some form of grading for 70 and HW Party, OH, etc. This is sort of indirect teaching experience, but certainly valuable for being a TA nonetheless. I don't think 61B has readers, only tutors, who do the same thing as CSM Mentors and some more things. CSM is managing most of 61B's tutors this semester too. 

That being said, to be honest: your role's title (mentor v. reader) matters far, far less than how good a job you do and who on course staff is able to speak to your abilities as being a good future TA.

children.subject:
For CS70, AI's responsibilities are helping out with homework parties / office hours / Guerilla sections; it's almost the same as reader expect AIs don't grade homework and don't get paid. 

For CS61B, CSM JM's responsibilities are almost the same as tutor responsibilities (teaching a small group discussion and other course staff stuff) while AIs help out during labs and OH. 

Tl; dr: Mudit's response above also applies to CSM JM vs AI.
The key thing really is: stand out, be noticed, go above and beyond, and try to make sure that someone on course staff is happy to recommend you at the end of the semester.
Can anyone comment on CSM Junior Mentor vs. Academic Intern for the same purpose?

history.content: I applied for both becoming a CSM and a reader for CS70 and CS61B. I want to eventually become a uGSI, and if I had to choose between the two, would it be better for me to be a mentor or a reader?
history.subject: CSM vs Reader
